Also, AI / machine learning application companies. I can provide some advice but am mostly hands off on my investments.
I’m interested in consumer internet companies that already have traction, are growing exponentially, and have a network effect.
I had backed off investing in startups the last few years, but due to the market I'm planning to start again.

@KevinSimler yeah, I think in all cases the benefit of the signal needs to be greater than the amount by which it makes life harder
@KevinSimler yeah. I think the only way to get a mostly honest signal is to have everyone waste a lot of resources making the sign
@KevinSimler I think the "handicap" is the cost of having to produce the sign and carry it, which turns out to be expensive but worth it.
@KevinSimler doesn't have to be expensive to produce an honest number as long as it's expensive to fake
@KevinSimler I'm not sure about the terms. But I think of it like a fitness score number on a sign they have to carry around and can't fake.
@KevinSimler I think you can view the tail as a signal that is hard to fake more than expensive. It carries information beyond the handicap.

@yishan yeah I could see that working. Though I still think you get most of the value of people host their own subreddits.
@ryaneshea anyway, I have to get to sleep. Good talking to you, I enjoyed the debate.
@ryaneshea ...they can't adapt
@ryaneshea zooming out... Even if you can replicate a lot of it, it's 10x the work to make them, the product ends up much worse, and
@ryaneshea but they can't do it well without being able to train on all the other users' view data, which can't be shared for privacy.
@ryaneshea my claim is that the number of useful mainstream applications where you could do this is very limited
@ryaneshea your original statement was that you can make decentralized systems do what centralized ones can do.
@ryaneshea woah, that is a totally different application. Who does the machine learning to rank the feed in that?
@muneeb amend my tweet: "whatever is going to be *broadcast* on the blockchain has the same issue"
@ryaneshea unlike Twitter, there are an unlimited number of other cachers that don't need to follow any rules
@ryaneshea @muneeb something would be stored on the blockchain, correct?
@muneeb @ryaneshea whatever is stored on the blockchain is going to have this issue. It's permanent, you can't enforce laws, you can't adapt
@ryaneshea it's too slow, so then there are caches all over with no incentive to remove old stuff. No one can enforce a terms of service.
@ryaneshea how do you design in practical deletion when everything is stored in public forever?
@ryaneshea when there are clear alternatives with none of those downsides, like running the reddit software on a server paid for by the mods
@ryaneshea it's not just about whether it's possible, it's about whether people want it with all the sacrifices that have to come with it
@ryaneshea and they value that ability
@ryaneshea you are really disconnected from mainstream users. In practice people can get stuff off the internet most of the time.
@ryaneshea @muneeb you get the worst of both worlds, not the "at worst" property
@ryaneshea @sama but with all the downsides of decentralization like speed and inflexibility
@ryaneshea @sama who gets the power to reverse stuff? You're back to a centralized authority.
@muneeb so again, if someone gets your password, you lose the account forever
@adrianbye you can still get hacked (e.g. By a virus that listens to your keyboard input). And in this model you lose your account forever.
@muneeb what goes on the "control plane"?
It's much better for marginalized subreddits to just move to other centralized platforms than to try to make it fully decentralized.
For example, if Twitter was implemented on it, and you lost your password, you could never get your account back. No deleting old tweets.
I'm not optimistic about the use of the blockchain for anything mainstream besides bitcoin. It has bad properties like irreversibility.

@giri_sreenivas if it wasn't a stretch, you would be able to give me an example of how it would happen
@giri_sreenivas Ok. I'm interested to hear about an example of abuse of cookies by advertisers. Re "historically that is ripe for abuse".
@giri_sreenivas Superfish didn't touch cookies.
@giri_sreenivas that's a security issue solved by SSL, plus was never something advertisers did because it didn't help them
@zackkanter @cdixon @Augur @PaulFoleyTweets so you are introducing security holes if you rely on them for login
@zackkanter @cdixon @Augur @PaulFoleyTweets the issue with those approaches is that they are not 100% accurate.
@giri_sreenivas @cdixon can you give me an example of "abuse"?
@giri_sreenivas @cdixon what exactly do you think would happen?
@giri_sreenivas @cdixon for the vast majority of people, advertising becoming more relevant is a good thing. Others can opt out.
@cdixon the model where every mobile app has its own browser with no shared cookies was a big mistake. Should at least be shared per device.
@cdixon didn't exist when people accessed everything through a single browser on a single computer
@cdixon someone needs to find a good way for cookies to get shared across apps and devices. That is the root of this problem.
